1. A 68-year-old male with a 50-pack-year smoking history presents with rapidly worsening dyspnea, persistent cough, and hemoptysis over the past month. He reports unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds and occasional chest discomfort. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the right upper lung field. A chest X-ray shows a large mass in the right upper lobe, and subsequent CT imaging confirms a 5 cm spiculated lesion with mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Bronchoscopy with biopsy demonstrates large pleomorphic cells with neuroendocrine features positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin. Laboratory tests show elevated serum neuron-specific enolase (NSE). Staging PET-CT shows no distant metastasis, classifying the tumor as stage III. The patient is counseled regarding aggressive chemoradiotherapy given the poor prognosis associated with large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung.
